File.Title: Topographically Organized Projections From the Nucleus Subcedeus to the Hypo@ossal Nucleus Rat: in the A Tjgcht and Electron Microscopic Study With Complementary Axonal Transport Techniques

Abstract.S: ABSTRACT

Projections from the nucleus subceruleus (nSC) to the hypoglossal nucleus (XII) were investigated with complementary retrograde and anterograde axonal transport techniques at the light and electron microscopic level in the rat.
Injections of WGA-HRP into XI1 resulted in labeling of neurons in and around the nSC.
Labeled nSC neurons were few in number ( < 4 per 40-60 km sections) and variable in size and shape.
Most labeled nSC neurons were medium-sized (x = 16.89 km), fusiform, triangular, or oval, with 3-4 dendrites typically oriented dorsomedially and ventrolaterally.
These neurons were found throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the nSC but were most numerous medial, dorsomedial, and ventromedial to the motor trigeminal nucleus.
Others were observed rostral to the motor trigeminal nucleus and ventral to the parabrachial nuclear complex.
Confirmation of retrograde results was obtained following injections of tritiated amino acids or WGA-HRP into the nSC.
This resulted in labeling throughout the rostrocaudal extent of XI1 mainly ipsilaterally.
Labeled fibers descended the brainstem in the dorsolateral and, to a lesser extent, in the ventromedial component of Probst s tract.
Fibers entered XI1 mainly rostrally along the lateral border of the nucleus.
All regions of XI1 were recipients of nSC afferents, but the caudoventromedial quadrant contained the greatest density of terminal labeling.
Electron microscopic evaluation confirmed that nSC afferents synapsed on motoneurons in XII.
Axon terminals containing WGA-HRP reaction product were found contacting dendrites and somata, but primarily the former (81.3% versus 10.6%).
Axodendritic terminals synapsed mainly on medium-to-small sized dendrites ( < 3 km in diameter).

The majority of labeled axodendritic terminals (90.1%) contained small, round, and clear synaptic vesicles (S-type: 20-50 nm) and were associated with an asymmetric (60.6%), symmetric (11.4%), or no (18%) postsynaptic specialization.
By contrast, most axosomatic terminals contained flattened vesicles (F-type) and formed a symmetric or no postsynaptic specialization (75%).
Large dense core vesicles (55-90 nm) were observed within a small proportion of all labeled axon terminals (1.3%).

The results from this study demonstrate that the nSC projects to XII, preferentially targets a specific subgrouping of protrusor motoneurons, and synapses on both somata and dendrites, although mainly on the latter.
The implications of these data are discussed relative to tongue control.

Introduction.S: The nucleus subceruleus (nSC) comprises a heterogeneous cell grouping in the dorsolateral rostral pontine tegmentum (Dahlstrom and Fuxe, '64; Maeda and Shimizu, '72; Andrezik and Beitz, '85; Paxinos and Watson, '86; Newman, '85; Rye et al., '87, '88).

Although the nSC contains both noradrenergic (NE) and non-NE neurons (Tohyama et al., '78; Satoh, '79; Rye et al., '87, '881, most investigations of the nSC have focused on the large NE neurons located immediately ventral to the locus ceruleus and dorsomedial to the motor trigeminal nucleus.

This cell grouping, defined initially with the locus ceruleus as the A6 catecholamine cell group (Dahlstrom and Fuxe, '641, the A6v (Hokfelt et al., '84), or part of the A7 group (Olson and Fuxe, '72; Westlund and Coulter, '80; Westlund et al., '82, '83), has been shown to have widespread projections throughout the neuraxis to sites including the periventricular preoptic area and hypothalamus (Maeda and Shimizu, '72; Olson and Fuxe, '721, spinal cord (Kuypers and Maisky, '75; Hancock and Fougerousse, '76; Nygren and Olson, '77; Satoh et al., '77; Satoh, '79; Tohyama et al., '78; Guyenet, '80; Westlund and Coulter, '80; Westlund et al., '82, '83), cerebellum (Tohyama et al., '781, and pons and medulla (Olson and Fuxe, '72; Levitt and Moore, '79).

Results from these and other studies provide evidence that the nSC is involved in a variety of somatic and visceral behaviors (Moore and Bloom, '79; Westlund and Coulter, '80; Westlund et al., '82; Bjorklund and Skagerberg, '82; Bjorklund and Lindvall, '86).

Of particular interest to this laboratory is evidence supporting a prominent role for the nSC in the modulation of motor reflexes (Westlund and Coulter, '80; Westlund et al., '82; Bjorklund and Skagerberg, '82), and involvement in oral motor behaviors such as respiration (Bertrand and Hugelin, '71; Bertrand et al., '73; Feldman and Gautier, '76) and phonation (Thoms and Jurgens, '87).

Since the tongue is an active participant in these behaviors (Sauerland and Mitchell, '70, '75; Remmers et al., '78; Brouillette and Thach, '79, '801, and reflexive control of the tongue is presumably an essential mechanism underlying this participation, I questioned whether motoneurons in the hypoglossal nucleus (XII) that innervate the tongue musculature (Ram6n y Cajal, '09; Barnard, '40) receive direct afferents from the nSC.

Although recent studies have documented nSC-XI1 projections in monkey (Westlund and Coulter, '80; Thoms and Jurgens, '871, this issue has not been adequently investigated in the rat (Jones andYang, '85; Rye et al., '87).

An additional impetus for this investigation was the observation that NE fibers terminate most prodigiously among a specific subgrouping of protrusor motoneurons in the caudoventromedial district of XI1 (Aldes et al., '88a,c; '90a,b).

Although it was previously reported that the nSC did not provide NE fibers to XI1 or other cranial nerve motor nuclei in the rat (Levitt and Moore, '791, recent results from this laboratory indicate the contrary (Chapman and Aldes, '89; Aldes et al., '90b in preparation).
In view of these conflicting observations, a second goal of the present study was to determine whether nSC afferents, if present, exhibit the same distribution pattern in XI1 as NE.

It will be demonstrated, on the basis of complementary retrograde and anterograde transport methodologies with confirmation of the latter at the electron microscopic level, that the nSC does indeed innervate XI1 in the rat, and that the nSC-XI1 projection is topographically organized and targets a specific subgrouping of protrusor motoneurons in the caudoventromedial district of XII.

Methods.S: MATERTALSANDMETHODS
Thirty-six female, Sprague-Dawley rats (Charles Rivers; 175-200 g) were used in this study.
All animals were anesthetized with a combination of ketamine hycirochloride (100 mgkg; IM) and acepromazine rnaleate (0.05 mgkg; IM) and secured in a stereotaxic frame (Kopf).
Retrograde studies

Wheat-germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP: 2% in 0.1 M Tris-HCl, pH 7.4) was iontophoretically delivered into XI1 in 10 animals through micropipettes (ID: 10-15 pm) as previously described (Aldes and Boone, '85; Aldes, '88b).
Injection parameters were 1.8-2.5 pAmps, positive DC, continuously for 8-12 minutes.

After 18-36 hours, animals were reanesthetized with Nembutal(75 mgkg; IP) and perfused-fixed transcardially with 2% paraformaldehyde, 1% glutaraldehyde, 1% sucrose in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) that was preceded by a 0.9% NaCl rinse.
Brains were post-fixed for 4-8 hours and rinsed overnight in buffer.
Brainstems were cut in the coronal plane on a Vibratome (Oxford) and serial sections, 40-60 pm thick, were processed with tetramethylbenzidine (TMB: Mesulam, '78).
Sections were mounted onto freshly coated slides, counterstained with neutral red and examined microscopically for retrogradely labeled neurons in and around the nSC and the injection site in XII.
A neuron was defined as retrogradely labeled by the presence of reaction product in the cell body and proximal dendrites.
Only labeled neurons with an identifiable nucleus were tabulated (N = 60).
Measurements of labeled neurons were made at lOOx under oil immersion with a calibrated eye piece reticle.
Major and minor axes were measured and the mean somal diameter was calculated for each labeled nSC Ja neuron according to the formula 2 (Jacquin et al., '83).
The distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons in the nSC was mapped onto drawings of the dorsolateral rostral pontine tegmentum with the aid of a microprojector (Bausch and Lomb).
Representative labeled nSC neurons were photographed.
A combination of tritiated amino acids (New England Nuclear: leucine, sp. act., 110-140 Ci/mMole and lysine, sp.
act., 60-80 Ci/mMole) was microiontophoretically injected into and around the nSC in 8 animals.
Animals were fixed by transcardial perfusion with 10% formal-saline after 7-14 days.
Brainstems were removed from the cranial vault and post-fixed for an additional 10-20 days.
Serial sections through the brainstem were cut frozen in the coronal plane at 25 pm and stored in fixative.
Every third section was processed for routine light microscopic autoradiography as previously described (Aldes and Boone, '85; Aldes, '88b).
Sections were counterstained with 0.1% thionin after development.

Sections were examined under darkfield illumination for the distribution of fibers and presumptive terminal fields in XII, and under brightfield illumination for elucidation of the focus and extent of injection sites.

Terminal fields were defined as silver grains organized in diffuse distribution patterns, while silver grains oriented in rows or clumped into clusters were considered preterminal axons (Aldes and Boone, '85; Aldes, '88b).
A grain count at least 20% above background defined a projection to XI1 (Aldes and Boone, '85).
Representative sections through the brainstem were drawn with the aid of a microprojector and selected sections through XI1 were photographed.
For electron microscopic evaluation, the nSC (N = 12) and sites adjacent to the nSC (N = 6) were microiontophoretically injected in different animals with WGA-HRP (2% in 0.1 M Tris-HC1, pH 7.4).
Injection parameters, survival times, perfusions, sectioning, and histochemistry are the same as described above.

Selected sections through XI1 were osmicated (1-2%, pH 5.5-6.0) for 1-2 hours, rinsed in buffer, dehydrated, infiltrated with Spurr resin, and flat-embedded between silanized glass microscope slides (Aldes and Boone, '84).

After the flat-embedded sections were cemented onto plastic pegs and a small etch-mark was placed in the plastic overlying the area in XI1 of interest, silver-to-gold sections were cut through this area on an ultramicrotome (LKB), placed on 200 copper mesh grids, stained with lead citrate (Reynolds), and examined in a Philips 301 transmission electron microscope.
Anterogradely labeled profiles in XI1 were identified by the presence of electron-dense TMB reaction product in the form of crystals.
A labeled profile was defined as synaptic by the presence of vesicles and a synaptic cleft with no intervening glial membrane.
A synaptic specialization was usually present.
Measurements of labeled profiles were made from negatives.
Quantitative analysis of labeled terminals was obtained directly from 75 clearly identifiable samples.

TTE.S: injections of wga - hrp were confined to xi1 in 4 animals and extended beyond the boundaries of xi1 in 6 animals .
in each case the distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons in the nsc was similar , but fewer neurons ( &&< 4 per section ) were labeled with smaller injections .
figure 1 is an example of an injection of wga - hrp confined largely to xii , with the resulting distribution pattern of retrogradely labeled nsc neurons illustrated in figure 2 .
labeled neurons were observed throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the nsc bilaterally , although primarily ipsilaterally ( fig . 2 ) .

others were observed further rostrally in a position medial to the kolliker - fuse nucleus and paralemniscus and ventral to the medial parabrachial nucleus ( fig . 2c , d ) .
labeled nsc nenurons were mainly medium sized ( x = 16 . 89 ?
2.071, fusiform, triangular, or oval, with 3-4 dendrites typically oriented dorsomedially and ventrolaterally (Fig. 3b,d,D.
a few medium - sized labeled nsc neurons exhibited vertically ( fig . 3a ) or horizontally ( fig . 3e ) oriented dendrites .
the latter were observed in the rostral nsc .
interspersed among the medium - sized nsc neurons were large ( x = 28 . 49 pm * 2 . 04 ) retrogradely labeled nsc neurons ( figs . 2a , b , 3c ) .
These neurons were multipolar, polygonal, with dendrites emanating in all directions, and were less frequently seen than medium-sized nSC neurons (15/60).
large nsc neurons were observed only along the medial aspect of the caudal half of the motor trigeminal nucleus ( fig . 2a , b ) .

other neuronal cell groups consistently labeled with injections confined to xi1 included the dorsal third of the principal sensory trigeminal nucleus , the supratrigeminal region , intertrigeminal region , the kolliker - fuse nucleus, and paralemniscus ( fig . 2 ) .

larger injections resulted in retrograde labeling of additional neuron groups in the dorsolateral rostral pontine tegmentum that included the lateral and medial parabrachial nuclei , locus ceruleus , and the nucleus pontis caudalis , as well as anterograde labeling in the lateral parabrachial and kolliker - fuse nuclei .
neurons in these sites were never seen labeled following injections confined to xii , nor was there any evidence of anterograde labeling in the parabrachial nuclear complex .
Light microscopy (autoradiography).
Figure 4 shows the focus and extent of an iontophoretic deposit of H3AA into the nSC.

The injection, confined to the nSCas defined by Andrezik and Beitz ('851, Paxinos and Watson ('86),' and Rye et al. ('88), encompassed an area bounded ventrally by the medial parabrachial nucleus and laterally by the Kolliker-Fuse nucleus rostrally (Fig. 4a), to the dorsomedial aspect of the motor trigeminal nucleus caudally (Fig. 4b).
neurons containing silver grains in the overlying emulsion were localized to this area ( fig . 4a , b ) .

at the level of the injection , labeled fibers coursed into adjacent areas that included the medial parabrachial and principal sensory trigeminal nuclei and the supratrigeminal region ( fig . 5a , b ) .
a sparse contingent of labeled fibers crossed the midline en route to the contralateral nsc , medial parabrachial nucleus , and supratrigeminal region ( fig . 5a , b ) .
After crossing the midline, a portion of the contralateral fiber projection turned ventrally and descended the brainstem ventromedially (Figs. 5).
the majority of labeled fibers descended the brainstem ipsilaterally in and around probst s tract in the dorsolateral reticular formation ( fig . 5c ) .
A similar tract was observed contralaterally but of considerably lesser intensity (Fig. 5C,D).

at midpontine levels , some ipsilateral fibers turned ventromedially and descended the brainstem in relation to the gigantocellular reticular fields ( fig . 5c - g ) and dorsal to inferior olivary complex ( fig . 5d - g ) .
en route , terminal labeling was seen in the facial motor nucleus ( fig . 5c ) and both in and around the nucleus ambiguus ( fig . 5c - f ) .
at medullary levels , fibers from probst s tract entered xi1 laterally and mainly rostrally ( fig . 5d - gi .

silver grains were seen distributed throughout all regions of xi1 ( figs . 5d - f , 6 ) however , the density of silver grains was greatest ventromedially in the caudal third of xi1 ( figs . 5f , g , 6 ) .

em-tte.S: figure 7a shows a typical injection of wga - hrp that was focused in the nsc .
the fringe of the injection extended minimally into the adjacent medial parabrachial and motor trigeminal nuclei .
a similar distribution pattern of preterminal and terminal labeling was observed with this injection as with the previously described isotope injection ( compare with fig . 4 ) .
light microscopic examination of flat - embedded sections revealed labeling throughout xii , but was most intense ipsilaterally in the caudoventromedial district ( fig . 7b ) .

at the electron microscopic level , profiles containing reaction product included myelinated ( fig . 8a ) and unmyelinated ( not shown ) axons , axon terminals ( figs . 8b - f , 9 ) , and a few dendrites ( not shown ) .
axon terminals containing wga - hrp reaction product were found ending on dendrites ( fig . 8 ) and motoneuron somata ( fig . 9 ) .
the majority of labeled terminals ended on medium - to - small sized dendrites ( &< 3 pm in diameter ) , although a few were encountered on larger , proximal dendrites .
overall , 81 . 3% of labeled axon terminals were axodendritic , 10 . 6% were axosomatic , and 8% did not make synaptic contact with any postsynaptic structure ( see table 1 ) .
The majority of axodendritic terminals (90.1%) contained small (20-50 nm), round, and clear, synaptic vesicles (S-type) and formed an asymmetric postsynaptic specialization (PSD; 60.6%).
Other S-type axodendritic terminals were associated with either a symmetric (11.4%) or no (18%) PSD.
s - type axodendritic terminals averaged 0 . 6 - 1 . 3 pm .

a few axodendritic terminals ( 9 . 8% ) contained a combination of round and flattened vesicles , i . e . , pleomorphic ( p - type ) or flattened vesicles ( f - type ) and were associated with a symmetric or no psd ( fig . 8d ) .
By contrast, axosomatic terminals (75%) typically contained flattened vesicles (F-type) and formed a symmetric or no PSD (Fig. 9a,b).
Other axosomatic terminals (25%) conformed to the S-type configuration seen most frequently on dendrites.

large dense core vesicles ( dcv : 55 - 90 nm ) , typically characterized by a dense central core and outer clear periphery , were observed in a small proportion ( 1 . 3% ) of all labeled axon terminals ( fig . 8c ) .
a small population of axon - like terminals ( 8% ) was observed that did not synapse on any postsynaptic structure ( fig . 8a ) .
Such profiles measured 0.6 x 0.8 pm, and contained numerous, small, round, densely packed, clear synaptic vesicles (20-50 nm) and large DCV (55-90) of varying sizes.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
The results from this study demonstrate that the nSC gives rise to a substantial contingent of afferents to XI1 in the rat.

The nSC-XI1 projection is chiefly ipsilateral, descends the brainstem dorsolaterally in Probst's tract, enters XI1 laterally, and terminates throughout XI1 but most heavily in the caudoventromedial district.
The conclusions reached in this study are based upon findings from complementarfr retrograde and anterograde studies with confirmation of the latter at the electron microscopic level.

These results extend recent findings in monkey (Westlund and Coulter, '80; Thoms and Jurgens, '87) to the rat and enforce the argument that the nSC plays an important, albeit enigmatic, role in tongue control (Aldes et al., '88a,c, '90a,b).
Previous studies in rat have commented little on nSC projections to XII.

Following injections of HRP into XII, investigators reported either no retrograde cell labeling in the dorsolateral rostral pontine tegmentum (Borke et al., '83) or sparse labeling of neurons around the motor trigeminal nucleus (Tokado et al., '82; Travers and Norgren, '83; Aldes and Boone, '85).
Recent results from retrograde transneuronal transport experiments with the Herpes simplex virus 1 also demonstrate labeled neurons throughout the rostral pons (Ugolini eb al., '87).
However, in none of these studies was the nSC delimited.

Based upon a synthesis of results from immunocytochemical (Swanson and Hartman, '75; Westlund et al., '82, '83; Grzanna et al., '87) histofluorescence (Dahlstrom and Fuxe, '64; Olson and Fuxe, '72; Hokfelt et al., '84) and recent cytoarchitectural (Andrezik and Beitz, '85; Paxinos and Watson, '86; Rye et al., '87, '88) studies, it is evident that the area medial to the motor trigeminal nucleus, which the present study has clearly demonstrated contains labeled neurons, comprises a significant region of the nSC.
Furthermore, the cell size, shape, and dendrite orientation is consistent with descriptions of nSC neurons (Tohyama et al., '78; Satoh, '79; Newman, '85; Westlund et al., '82).

Additional evidence suggesting an nSC-XI1 projection is derived from autoradiographic studies in which portions of the nSC were included in the fringe of injections centered at adjacent sites in the dorsolateral rostra1 pontine tegmentum (Jones and Yang, '85; Rye et al., '88).

By confining injections of isotope (Fig. 4) and WGA-HRP (Fig. 7a) to the nSC and demonstrating a topographically organized projection to XI1 (Figs. 5D,F, 6, 7b), the present results both clarify and extend the findings of these autoradiographic studies and confirm the results of previously described retrograde experiments (Figs. 1-3).
The most striking observation in the present study was that nSC afferents terminated throughout all regions of XI1 but predominantly caudoventromedially (Figs. 5D-F, 6, 7b).

This finding is significant in view of recent studies demonstrating that both direct (Aldes et al., '88a,c, '90; Ermini and Aldes, '88; Chapman and Aldes, '89) and indirect (Mameli and Tolu, '85, '86) afferent systems target the same region of XII.
The convergence of multifunctional inputs here suggests an important and perhaps unique functional role for this region in tongue control.

Although protrusor motoneurons are contained in this district (Barnard, '40; Lewis et al., '711, it is controversial whether they innervate the genioglossus muscle (Krammer et al., '791, the major extrinsic protrusor of the tongue (Bole and Lessler, '66), or the intrinsic protrusor musculature (verticalis and transversus: Doran and Baggett, '72; Doran, '75) of the tip and apex (Uemera-Sumi et al., '88).
Resolution of this issue is of obvious importance for the accurate interpretation of the present data and is currently being investigated.
Electron microscopic observations demonstrating labeled axon terminals synapsing in XI1 following injection of WGA-HRP into the nSC confirms the existence of the nSC-XI1 projection.
Labeled axon terminals were found to synapse on dendrites (Fig. 8) and somata (Fig. 91, although predominantly on the former (Table 1).

The finding of labeled axosomatic and axodendritic terminals is consistent with the patterns seen at the light microscopic level where presumptive preterminal axons and terminals were seen throughout all regions of XI1 (Figs. 6,7b).

The predominant axodendritic distribution of labeled terminals in XI1 is not surprising in view of the extensive dendritic field domains of XI1 motoneurons (Ramon y Cajal, '09; Odutola, '76; Wan et al., '82).

Moreover, this pattern is consistent with previous reports regarding the organization and distribution of axon terminals in XI1 (Boone and Aldes, '84b; Aldes and Boone, '85; Borke and Nau, '85, '87; Borke et al., '88; Aldes et al., '89, '90a).

It cannot be determined from the present experiments, however, upon which specific population of motoneurons (retrusor versus protrusor) nSC afferents terminate since extensive intermingling of dendrites occurs throughout XI1 (Odutola, '76; Wan et al., '82).
This issue is currently under investigation.
The morphology of labeled nSC axon terminals was variable.
Axodendritic terminals contained mainly small, round, agranular synaptic vesicles (S-type) and typically formed an asymmetric PSD (Fig. 8b,c,e,f).
A few were associated with a symmetric or no PSD.
S-type axodendritic terminals also occasionally contained large DCV (55-90 nm) that were characterized by a dense central core and outer clear periphery (Fig. 8c).
Only a few axodendritic terminals contained a mixture of round, clear, and flattened vesicles (P-type: Fig. 8d) or exclusively flattened vesicles (F-type).
By contrast, most axosomatic terminals were F-type and formed either a symmetric or no PSD (Fig. 9), although S-type axosomatic terminals with an asymmetric PSD were also encountered.

The variation in morphology of labeled axon terminals is consistent with light microscopic observations that nSC neurons of different sizes and shapes project to XI1 (Fig. 31, and is in accord with previous studies that demonstrated multiple cell types in the nSC (Tohyama et al., '78; Satoh, '79; Newman, '85; Rye et al., '88).
This morphologic heterogeneity likely underlies both physiologic and pharmacologic differences, the nature of which remains to be determined.
Sand F-type terminals have been shown to terminate primarily on dendrites and somata in XII, respectively (Boone and Aldes, '84b).
The prasent results provide evidence that nSC afferents follow a similar pattern.

These results are generally consistent with the distribution patterns of trigeminal-XI1 axon terminals (Aldes and Boone, '85; Borke and Nau, '87; Borke et al., '881, but appear to differ from those derived from reticule-XI1 afferents (Borke and Nau, '85; Borke et al., '88).
Additional studies are required to clarify the extent to which different afferent systems projecting to XI1 exhibit unique synaptic distribution patterns.
From a functional viewpoint, Sand F-type terminals have been correlated with excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission, respectively (Uchizuno, '65).

Although the validity of this concept has not been universally established, if one assumes its accuracy relative to XII, one would predict a dominant excitatory or facilitatory affect on XI1 motoneuron activity by the nSC that is directed primarily at distal dendrites ( &amp;amp;lt; 3 km in diameter).

Although speculative, especially since the effects of nSC afferents on XI1 motoneurons are unknown, it is likely that this input plays an important role in establishing or modifying the background level of XI1 motoneuron activity and/or in modulating tongue reflexes.
Furthermore, it is likely that this input is but a single component of a complex, integrative network that is involved in modulating a variety of oral motor behaviors.

That nSC terminal fields were found within the motor trigeminal, facial, and ambiguus nuclei supports this hvDothesis (Fie. 5). and is consistent with recent findings in u mdnkey (Thoms and Jurgens, '87).

The possibility that labeled axon terminals occurred as a result of spurious uptake of WGA-HRP by non-nSC neurons whose axons traversed the injection site en route to XI1 requires additional comment since other components of the dorsolateral rostra1 pontine tegmentum including the principal sensory trigeminal nucleus (Aldes and Boone, '851, parabrachial nuclear complex (Saper and Loewy, '80; Tokado et al., '82; Travers and Norgren, '83; Ermini and Aldes, '881, and supratrigeminal region (Tokado et al., '82; Travers and Norgren, '83; Aldes and Boone, '85) project to XII.
However, militating against the likelihood of this possibility is the consistent lack of retrogradely labeled neurons in these sites following discrete injections into the nSC.
Such labeling would be anticipated if significant axonal uptake had occurred.

Furthermore, the course and terminal distribution patterns of these afferents are different from the nSC in that they do not preferentially target the caudoventromedial quadrant of XI1 (Aldes and Boone, '85; Ermini and Aldes, '88).

These observations are consistent with the view that WGA-HRP shows little propensity for anterograde transport by damaged axons or fibers-en-passage in the CNS (Steindler, '82; Grob et al., '82; Brodal et al., '83).

Of further interest is the observation that the terminal distribution pattern of nSC afferents found in this study is strikingly similar to that previously reported for NE projections to XI1 (Aldes et al., '88a,c, '90a).

Moreover, the synaptic distribution (mainly axodendritic) and the morphology of labeled nSC terminals (mainly S-type) correlates closely with previously described NE axon terminals in XI1 (Aldes et al., '90a).

In view of these correlations, and the fact that the nSC is a major repository of NE neurons (Dahlstrom and Fuxe, '64; Swanson and Hartman, '75; Hokfelt et al., '841, it is reasonable to question if, and to what extent, nSC-XI1 projections are NEergic.

The fact that Probst's tract, the route by which nSC afferents reach XI1 (Fig. 5C-F), and the medullary catecholamine bundle, the major descending NE pathway (Hokfelt et al., '841, occupy overlapping positions in the dorsolateral reticular formation (compare Fig. 144, p. 370, Hokfelt et al., '84 to Fig. 71, Paxinos and Watson, '86) provides additional support for this consideration.

However, Levitt and Moore, ('79) concluded on the basis of biochemical and histofluorescence methodologies that the nSC and locus ceruleus were not sources of NE to XI1 or other cranial nerve motor nuclei.

Yet, results from this laboratory using contemporary doublelabeling immunocytochemical techniques strongly suggest that NE-containing neurons in and around the nSC do indeed project to XI1 in rat (Chapman and Aldes, '89; Aldes et al., '90b in preparation).

Since the nSC contains both NE and non-NE neurons (Tohyama et al., '78; Satoh, '79; Newman, '85; Rye et al., '87, '881, and results from the present study show that different cell types in the nSC project to XI1 (Fig. 3), it is likely that both NE and non-NE neurons contribute to the innervation of XII.
Interestingly, NE and non-NE nSC neurons have been shown to have similar projection patterns in the spinal cord (Toyhama et al., '78), and a similar relationship may exist in XII.
A more complete discussion of this issue will be presented in a separate communication (Aldes et al., in preparation).
Also noteworthy is the observation that retrogradely labeled neurons were found in XI1 following WGA-HRP injection into the nSC.
This was confirmed at the electron microscopic level by the finding of retrogradely labeled somata and dendrites (not shown).
These neurons were not distributed evenly throughout XI1 but were restricted mainly to dorsolateral, lateral, and ventral margins (Fig. 7b).
Interneurons have been described in XI1 (Cooper, '81; Boone and Aldes, '84a; Takasu and Hashimoto, '88; Davidoff and Schulze, '88) and show a similar distribution.
Furthermore, interneurons of XI1 have been reported to project to other cranial nerve motor nuclei including the motor trigeminal nucleus (Aldes, '88a).
Since injections of WGA-HRP included part of the latter, the possibility remains that labeled interneurons in XI1 observed in the present study project to the motor trigeminal nucleus.

Alternatively, interneurons of XI1 may also project to other interneuron groups around the motor trigeminal nucleus, in this case the nSC, and contribute to the integrative network described in a preceding paragraph.
Future experiments will resolve this issue.

In conclusion, the nSC is involved in oral motor behaviors including phonation (Thoms and Jurgens, '87) and respiration (Bertrand and Hugelin, '71; Bertrand et al., '73; Feldman and Gautier, '76) as well as in general motor reflex control (Westlund and Coulter, '80; Westlund et al., '82; Bjorklund and Skagerberg, '82; Bjorklund and Lindvall, '86).

Reflex activation of the tongue has been extensively investigated (see Dubner et al., '78; Loewe, '841, and the relationship between respiration and tongue activity is well known (Sauerland and Mitchell, '70, '75; Remmers et al., '78; Brouillette and Thach, '79, '80).
The present results provide the anatomical basis underlying the involvement of the nSC, probably via both NE and non-NE mechanisms, in tongue control relative to these behaviors.
Future investigations must evaluate the functional organization of these substrates.
